full_title_en: Veterans Health Administration COVID-19 (VACO) Index for COVID-19 Mortality
medium_description_en: Estimates risk of 30-day mortality after COVID-19 infection using pre-COVID health status.
before_use:
Developed in collaboration with the US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), including the CDC, NIH, VA, and the ASPR.

This calculator was developed and validated in VA cohorts, and then externally validated in a non-VA patient population, noteworthy because of the VA's predominantly male population. The VACO Index predicts well in all subpopulations in which it was studied.

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• The VACO Index estimates 30-day all cause mortality after COVID-19 infection, incorporating demographic data and pre-existing conditions.
  • The VACO Index can be used to screen uninfected patients to identify those at a higher risk of dying should they develop COID-19.
  • While not specifically studied, infected individuals at higher risk of death have more severe disease that is more likely to require hospitalization and intubation.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• The VACO Index uses demographic and preexisting condition data available in electronic health record and billing data to predict 30-day mortality, and does not require current clinical data. This makes the Index very useful to target high-risk patients within a health system's population.
  • The VACO Index has been validated in two internal cohorts and in one external cohort, a significant advantage over many other COVID-19 risk scores.

next_steps.advice_en: The VACO Index research group is currently in the process of developing an acute model, supplementing the VACO Index with BMI, vital signs, and laboratory values to inform acute COVID-19 management.

about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
The VACO Index was derived from VA patients with positive COVID-19 testing in their health system; it was derived based on 3,681 patients, then validated in two separate internal cohorts. 2,151 were included in its "early validation" and 7,491 in its "late" validation, based on the date of the first positive test for COVID-19.

As suspected, age itself was predictive of mortality, especially when the Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI) was included in the risk model. Since the CCI incorporates a patient's entire spectrum of comorbidities, myocardial infarction and peripheral vascular disease were the other two independent predictors of mortality once the CCI was included. The authors speculate that this " information underscores the likely importance of thrombotic complications in COVID-19." 

Since the VACO Index was derived and developed on patients early in the COVID-19 pandemic, and testing was especially limited at that time, it may slightly over-estimate mortality risk in later patients, as seen in the study's late validation cohort. It may also be that additional experience with COVID-19 has led to better management of patients, lowering mortality compared to at the beginning of the pandemic. For example, the authors note "Overall mortality rate in our development cohort was nearly three times that found in our most recent validation cohort (13% vs 5%)." The authors note as testing capacity increases, more patients will be tested for COVID-19, likely reducing the mortality rate (by increasing the denominator).

This calculator does include race in its analysis and derivation of its risk model, with non-Hispanic white patients having higher mortality. However, after adjustment for age and CCI, these racial differences vanished. Race was categorized based on VA record sets.

Validation.text: King JT, Yoon JS, Bredl ZM, et al. Accuracy of the Veterans Health Administration COVID-19 (Vaco) Index for predicting short-term mortality among 1,307 Yale New Haven Hospital inpatients and 427,224 Medicare patients. medRxiv. Published online January 4, 2021:2021.01.01.20249069.

Original/Primary Reference.text: King JT Jr, Yoon JS, Rentsch CT, Tate JP, Park LS, Kidwai-Khan F, Skanderson M, Hauser RG, Jacobson DA, Erdos J, Cho K, Ramoni R, Gagnon DR, Justice AC. creator_info.about_en: Joseph King Jr., MD, MSCE, FAANS, is an Associate Professor of Neurosurgery and Director of Neurosurgical Outcomes Research at the Yale School of Medicine in Connecticut, and the Chief of Neurosurgery at the VA Connecticut Healthcare System. Dr. King's primary research is focused on using large databases to examine health care systems issues, the measurement of patient-oriented outcomes and quality of life in patients with neurologic disease.

Amy Justice, MD, PhD, is the CNH Long Professor of Medicine and of Public Health at Yale University and a Staff Physician at the VA Connecticut Healthcare System. As principal investigator of the Veterans Aging Cohort Study (VACS), she has more than 20 years of experience developing and validating predictive indices using electronic health record data.

James S. Yoon is a third year medical student at Yale School of Medicine in Connecticut. His research focuses on value-based healthcare aimed at improving patient experiences through policy reforms, delivery system innovation, and outcomes research that informs safe, evidence-based clinical practices.
